Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Predictors of Children's Lying to Conceal Parental Transgression

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
It is vital for society to protect children from abuse. However, child abuse victims are emotionally attached to their parents, and thus these young victims will sometimes lie to conceal parental transgressions, even serious transgressions such as child abuse. Abused children may be afraid of losing their parent and entering foster care, and therefore lie to protect their parents, despite the falsehood increasing the chance of the children staying in an abusive home. It is important, therefore, to identify parenting variables and parent-child relationship factors that predict whether or not children will lie to conceal a parental transgression. This study will help guide theory regarding social predictors of children's lying behavior. T his new knowledge will be of use forensically given the likelihood that child victims who create this type of falsehood would remain in detrimental environments and not receive necessary protection.

This research examines whether parenting style, child attachment, and parental attachment relate to children's lying to project their parents. A second goal of the research is to determine whether children's willingness to lie changes when the cost for lying varies. Parent-child dyads, with children ranging from 8- to 12- years of age, will be given well-validated measures of parenting and attachment to complete, and then take part in a semi-scripted transgression scenario. The children will be questioned regarding the transgressions, either with an implied high cost or an implied low cost, and responses will be coded for lying behavior. Regression models will determine whether the social variables and the cost manipulation predict children?s lying.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Interest in the topic of children’s lie-telling and truth-telling behavior has increased in the last few decades. This renewed interest is due in part to the forensic implications of children’s lying, as the role of child witnesses in the legal system has grown. Children’s lie-telling and their motivation to do so is of interest forensically because children can be called on to testify as witnesses or victims of criminal behavior or of child abuse. The accused, when children testify, may be one of the children’s family members including parents. In these cases, children’s statements are evaluated by legal professionals for the veracity of the testimony, which is a judgment as to whether children are telling the truth or lying.

One lie of concern that children might tell could result in a case never being brought to trial. This lie occurs when children conceal a transgression, such as parental abuse. Why would abused children want to protect the abuser? A likely answer to this question rests in the relationship children have with their parents. Therefore the goal of this study was to examine how parenting and attachment might relate to whether children lie to protect their parents.

The funds from this award permitted us to recruit 98 parent-child dyads from the community for a two-hour, one-visit session. Eight additional dyads participated in a pilot of the study. All dyads were tested individually. Once parents and their children arrived at the laboratory they were greeted by the experimenter and a research assistant whereupon they were consented. Children were brought into a testing room to complete their first activity. While the children were preoccupied, the painting scenario was explained to the parents.

The children were then brought to a second testing room for another set of research tasks. The parents joined them for the last activity. They were alone together at this time. As soon as parents completed their activity, they got up, walked towards the painting, and while inspecting it, dropped it. Upon picking it up, they exclaimed audibly “I ripped it” and that “hopefully no one will notice.” The parents then sat back down, and the experimenter soon re-entered and escorted them out of the room while the research assistant came back to help the children finish. The research assistant then noticed the rip and asked the children, “What happened to the painting?”

A “cost” to lying was experimentally manipulated. Specifically, for half the children, prior to the first question about the rip, the research assistant noted that the painting was an original. For the other half, the research assistant noted that the painting was a copy. Then, after the children answered the question, the research assistant called over the experimenter and mentioned the rip in the painting. During their interaction, the experimenter corrected the research assistant by changing “copy” to “original” or vice-versa. By correcting the research assistant, the cost of lying was either increased or decreased. The experimenter then left the room, and the research assistant asked the children again, “What happened to the painting?” After the children answered the second question, they rejoined their parents and were debriefed by the experimenter.

Several child factors and parental factors influenced children’s decisions to cover up the parental transgression by lying. The child factors that were significant predictors of lying were child age and working memory. An increase in age increased the likelihood of telling this type of lie, and an increase in working memory also predicted increased lying. Parenting style predicted lying, such that an increase in authoritative parenting predicted an increase in lying. Attachment security tapped in preschool and again in middle childhood related to lying, but interacted with child gender. Although the cost manipulation did not predict children’s lying, asking children a second time about what happened did affect lying behavior: Children were less likely to lie when asked a second time.

Implications of the findings extend past the theoretical into the applied area of legal psychology. Children are sometimes interviewed by legal professionals (e.g., district attorneys, child protection workers) as possible victims of parental abuse or as witnesses to domestic violence. In these cases, the people of interest may be family members of the children, often even the parents. During these interviews, children may lie to cover up the abuse or violence. Understanding why they choose to lie may be helpful in understanding which children are lying and which are not. This study provides preliminary evidence as to factors that affect children’s willingness to lie to cover up parental transgressions. The results of this study also have implications for how interviews should be conducted, as repeated questioning during interviews may influence children’s willingness or ability to maintain the lie.
